Personally, I believe in BOTH capital punishment and abortion. I also believe that we need laws if we are to have a society.

 
 In general, I think the death penalty should be dropped. But I think if it were to be applied, this is a case that fits. (Btw, this is something I stated on the other forum thread, too, that the oh-so-authentic DrNo would "know".)
 
 At the very least, I think offenders who cannot be rehabilitated and are continuing threats to society should be locked up without possibility of parole.
 
 I am sympathetic to everyone's constitutional right to due process, but I am very victim and victims' family sympathetic. I am also a Second Amendment supporter (within reasonable constraints) who is able to handle a gun (though some forms of self-defense are actually much more deadly and effective -- and I DO believe in people's right to defend themselves with equal or greater force, including butt slaps, too bad about the unforseen consequences to the ******* who reached over while propelled forward on a bicycle).
 
 My thoughts on the death penalty are partly based on morality, but also a questioning one (i.e. I am not convinced that some people don't deserve the death penalty), and more about the pragmatics of our system and great inequalities as to who gets axed (i.e. minorities more than whites).
 
 But isn't it odd that many anti-abortion proponents are death penalty supporters. Yet instead of skipping their minimally First Degree Murder (which is a death penalty case) hero down the hallway to the execution chamber, suddenly they want exactly what they've been harping about in the courts for years.

The killer had no right to take the doctor's life. The doctor had a right to perform the legal abortions. There is a difference. Though I disagree that late term abortions should be allowed (except when the mother's life is in danger) I accept the FACT that the doctor was operating within legal boundaries when doing his work.
 
 Killing people simply because they do something you don't like is definitely against the law here in the US of A.

 
 Did you not just read what I posted? Seriously read it again. I said that the killer was wrong. Just because something is legal doesn't mean I have to think its right. Its legal to rape your wife in some countries does that mean if the women sets the man on fire that I can't think he deserved it?
Chuz Life

The killer had no right to take the doctor's life. The doctor had a right to perform the legal abortions. There is a difference. Though I disagree that late term abortions should be allowed (except when the mother's life is in danger) I accept the FACT that the doctor was operating within legal boundaries when doing his work.
 
 Killing people simply because they do something you don't like is definitely against the law here in the US of A.

 
 I don't disagree with you Jim,... But I have to wonder where the breaking point is. Clearly our country (the USA) was founded by a bunch of angry people who revolted against the King and his injustices. Many thousands were killed in the revolutionary war. The abortion issue is unique in that if we who oppose abortion are correct, millions upon millions of babies have been unjustly denied their rights and their lives by this government. That's far more barbaric than even slavery was. And slavery too was at the root of a war here in the U.S.
 
 With awareness comes responsibility.
 
 I remember a prolifer once challenging me,... she said: "If you truly believe that an abortion is a murder,... ACT like it."
 
 I do not condone the murders of abortion doctors. I believe that it harms the anti-abortion cause far more than it does us any good.
 
 But like Ryuichi,... I completely understand it and I'm surprised that enough of us have sufficient restraint to keep it from happening more often. 
 
 Still, I wonder where the breaking points are; both for the individual and for the "pro-life" "anti-abortion" half of the country as a whole.
Ryuuichi

Now,.. if you could only prove that elective abortion achieves this goal,.... You just might (MIGHT) make me reconsider my views on the matter. 
 
 Unfortunately, I have to consider that even the intellectually challenged among us have a right to live the lives they are living and to not have their rights denied except by due process.
 
 But,... hmmmm. 
 
 Tempting.

 
 Darwin Awards: 2008 Darwin Awards 
 
 There has to be at least one fool their that should have been aborted. Clouding up the gene pool. Too Dumb To Live to the fullest. A One Track Mind is the perfect example. Lulzy as heck too.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  The man who killed the abortionist George should be free
